literature.title: Dutch Pharmacogenetics Working Group (DPWG) guideline for the gene-drug interaction of CYP2C9, HLA-A and HLA-B with anti-epileptic drugs.

relatedGenes.name: major histocompatibility complex, class I, A

summaryMarkdown.html: Consider an alternative drug to carbamazepine in patients with the HLA-A*3101 allele.

textMarkdown.html:
Dutch Pharmacogenetics Working Group (DPWG) guideline for the gene-drug interaction of CYP2C9, HLA-A and HLA-B with anti-epileptic drugs. European journal of human genetics (2024)

The Royal Dutch Pharmacists Association - Pharmacogenetics Working Group published a paper with guidelines for carbamazepine and HLA-A including Supplementary materials [Article:38570725].

Wording in table taken from Table 2 - rows for carbamazepine and HLA-A [Article:38570725] and Supplementary table 17

Genotype-(group) or phenotype Description Therapeutic recommendation
HLA-A*3101 positive An increased risk of the life-threatening cutaneous side effects DRESS and Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis (SJS/TEN) within the first three months is present in patients with this genetic variation. The risk of carbamazepine-induced DRESS in these patients is 0.89%. - Carefully weigh the risk of DRESS and SJS/TEN against the benefits.
- Avoid carbamazepine if an alternative is possible.
- If it is not possible to avoid carbamazepine, advise the patient to report any skin rash immediately.

The clinical implication score for HLA-A*31:01- carbamazepine in all patients and HLA-B*15:11-carbamazepine in patients of Han Chines, Korean, Thai or Japanese descent is “beneficial”. For detailed information see Supplementary table 20c.

The annotation of the DPWG guideline for carbamazepine and HLA-B can be found here.

May 2021 Guideline

The Royal Dutch Pharmacists Association - Pharmacogenetics Working Group (DPWG) has evaluated recommendations for carbamazepine based on the presence of the HLA-A*3101 allele. For recommendation wording, see Dutch guidelines May 2021 update.

Read for more information about this recommendation, Read about gene information from DPWG

Preemptive genotyping

Excerpts from the DPWG risk analysis document for carbamazepine and HLAs:

The KNMP Pharmacogenetics Working Group considers HLA-B*1502 genotyping of patients of Asian, other than Japanese descent, HLA-A*3101 genotyping, and HLA-B*1511 genotyping of patients of Han Chinese, Korean, Thai or Japanese descent before starting carbamazepine to be beneficial for drug safety. It is advised to consider genotyping these patients before (or directly after) drug therapy has been initiated to guide drug selection.

Read more about how DPWG assigns their recommendations for preemptive genotyping.
